values.alignmentText: Strong enterprise demand nationwide.
Improving yet wildfire smoke and urban pollution remain issues.
Religious diversity; atheism accepted mainly in cities.
Polarization raises concerns though institutions remain resilient.
Advanced banking and fintech options.
Many beaches across coasts though often crowded or seasonal.
Strong hobby market with major conventions.
Minimal federal support and costly services.
Varies widely; some cities are car-centric with few parks.
No universal childcare; federal/state credits/subsidies exist but coverage varies; costs high in many metros.
Eligibility for subsidies/credits varies by status and state; many programs limited to residents/citizens; documentation required.
Sports, gaming, and outdoor recreation.
Can be friendly yet individualistic depending on region.
Low risk; rights protected under law.
High in major cities, moderate elsewhere.
Generally allowed; the US tolerates dual nationality though obligations to both countries apply.
Large dynamic economy with cyclical volatility.
Capitalist economy with limited welfare state.
Top universities but uneven K-12 quality.
H-1B and other visas exist but are quota limited.
Wide range from pristine wilderness to polluted areas depending on region.
Moderate federal plus varying state taxes.
Generally pleasant in many regions; hurricane risk on SE/Gulf coasts; North cools earlier; foliage seasons vary.
Diverse experiences but limited social supports.
Family members are citizens with full rights.
No federal paid parental leave; FMLA unpaid; state-level paid leave in a few states; childcare tax credits limited.
Limited parental leave and benefits.
Similar constraints; employer policies matter; state benefits often residency‑linked; immigration status can limit access.
Diverse from minimalist to athleisure; regional climates drive layering; strong beauty/fitness culture in metros.
Urban smart‑casual/streetwear; athleisure; regional outdoors styles; wide variance by city/scene.
Varied expectations from traditional to progressive.
Strong industry with many opportunities.
Legal recognition increasing though backlash exists.
Legal protections exist but vary by state.
Improving equality yet persistent stereotypes.
SSN, banking, driver licence; employer‑tied insurance common; healthcare costs high without coverage; maintain status/travel docs.
High exposure to hurricanes, wildfires, and heatwaves.
High quality but expensive and often tied to employment.
Private insurance required with high costs.
Large public/private system; in‑state tuition benefits; federal aid/loans; costs high but options broad.
International tuition common; limited federal aid; scholarships institution‑dependent; pathways improve with PR/citizenship.
High prices in many cities; affordability crisis ongoing.
Complex annual filing system.
Free public schooling; quality varies by district; secular curriculum with local control; school choice options vary by state.
Most dependents can attend public school as residents; documentation/zoning apply; ESL supports often available.
English is dominant with high ubiquity.
Legal protections nationally; acceptance varies by state.
Generally skeptical; limited to academic circles.
Emphasis on independence and work focus.
Extensive meetups and social groups across interests.
Low federal rate with wide state variation.
Advanced infrastructure though aging in some regions.
Diverse national parks and landscapes.
Significant risks from hurricanes, tornadoes, and earthquakes.
National and state parks provide wide access to nature.
Vibrant scenes in major cities.
Major metros vibrant (NYC, LA, Chicago); suburban/rural quieter; closing times vary; safety varies by neighborhood.
GDC and numerous local groups foster networking.
Major studios like EA, Blizzard, and Microsoft.
Venture capital and accelerators available for startups.
Fast in cities with variation elsewhere.
High extracurricular and academic pressure in many regions.
Already citizens by birth.
Moderate; lobbying and money in politics.
Federal republic with checks and balances but high polarization.
Growing communities though legal risks exist in custody cases.
Patchwork of private centers and in‑home care; availability, quality, costs vary widely by state/metro; waitlists common in cities.
Extensive private options (religious/secular); tuition substantial in major metros; admissions selective at top schools.
Highly polarized with progressive enclaves and conservative regions.
Themes of patriotism and consumerism common.
Private media with partisan slant.
Robust in some cities but poor nationally.
Significant influence of religion in policy debates.
Remote work common in tech though some pushback exists.
Citizenship provides permanent rights.
Social Security + employer plans (401k/IRA); adequacy varies by savings/healthcare costs; Medicare at 65.
Social Security access after contributions; private savings common.
Eligibility depends on contributions/status; plan portability varies; totalization treaties may help; Medicare access limited pre‑PR.
Good demand in startups though declining overall.
Higher gun violence than peers; varies by city.
Quality varies by district; options include charter and private schools.
Warm in southern states and colder in northern regions.
Varies drastically; some regions experience extreme conditions.
Mixed attitudes with conservative and liberal regions.
Patchwork of progressive and conservative laws.
Highly regional: North ~5–15 °C (41–59 °F), South ~10–22 °C (50–72 °F); variable rain; tornado season in central US.
Generally stable but political unrest possible.
Market-oriented capitalism.
Strong free-market system.
Many regions hot/humid (Midwest/South 25–35 °C / 77–95 °F); West can be hot/dry; heat waves and wildfire smoke episodic.
No costs or wait for citizens; visas for others can be lengthy.
Low trust levels among the public.
Legalized influence and occasional scandals.
High salaries in major tech hubs like San Francisco and Seattle.
Youth sports, errands, parks, faith/community events; retail widely open; regional car‑centricity shapes plans.
Schools often ~08:00–15:00; offices ~08:30–17:30; after‑school care varies by district; commute times vary by metro.
No federal minimum; typically 10 days.
Two to three weeks in many tech roles.
Generally friendly toward Canada and Mexico.
Sees itself as a global leader and exceptional nation.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as powerful but sometimes overbearing.
Diverse visa types but complex and competitive.
This is home country; citizens already welcome.
Entrepreneurial culture and innovation hubs.
North: freezing temps/snow; Midwest can be severe; South/West milder; ice storms possible; big regional variance.
Standard 40 hours but many roles expect more.
Often poor with long hours culture.
Limited protections compared to Europe and weak unions.
